author: By S. Isabelle
title: 6 Terrific Witchy Y.A. Novels
description: S. Isabelle, the author of “The Witchery” and its sequel, “Shadow Coven,” recommends some of her favorite Y.A. novels about witches.
content: My fascination with witchy characters began in childhood, when I often imagined myself with the powers I read about in fantasy novels. I’ll never tire of meeting characters who manipulate magic, whether they’re inspired by real cultural histories or common fantasy tropes. Thankfully, witches are a timeless fixture in literature, and the following books are incredible additions to the Y.A. canon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Roasts Mike Johnson
description: Stephen Colbert called the new House speaker “the most generic-sounding congressional leader since the election of Speaker James Kirkland Brand.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Alcohol Might Be Ruining Your Orgasm
description: How much and how often you drink can affect your ability to climax during sexual activity.
content: Emma Schmidt, a clinical sexologist in Cincinnati, has lost track of the number of clients she’s seen for low libido and problems orgasming after they’ve first visited a doctor who advised them to “Just relax and have a glass of wine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. Eugene Steuerle and Glenn Kramon
title: For the Good of the Country, Older Americans Should Work More and Take Less
description: Congress’s refusal to adjust Social Security and Medicare means older Americans consume more of the country’s resources at the expense of the young.
content: We older Americans are not only controlling national politics; we are consuming an ever larger share of our economy’s resources through programs like Social Security and Medicare, leaving younger Americans to foot growing bills for their parents’ and grandparents’ retirements. And politicians of both parties are refusing to recognize the consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Michael Tracy, Who Made Subway Trains His Canvas, Dies at 65
description: Using the name Tracy 168, he was a pioneering graffiti artist during the tumultuous 1970s and ’80s in New York.
content: Michael Tracy, a Bronx-bred graffiti artist known as Tracy 168 who turned subway cars into rolling canvases for his spray paint murals, becoming a breakout star of the New York streets in the 1970s in an outlaw medium that became central to early hip-hop culture, died on Sept. 3 in the Bronx. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Hasan Minhaj Addresses Embellished Stories Detailed by The New Yorker
description: The stand-up comedian said he thought “the lines between truth and fiction were allowed to be a bit more blurry” in his personal storytelling.
content: The comedian Hasan Minhaj released a 21-minute video on Thursday, addressing a New Yorker article that chronicled fabrications of personal experiences he recounted in his stand-up specials, and apologizing to those who felt “betrayed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: As Winter Nears, Ukraine Braces for Attacks on Energy Grid
description: Russia targeted power systems last year and recent attacks suggest a return to that strategy, raising anxiety among Ukrainian civilians and officials.
content: Russian drone strikes near a nuclear power plant in western Ukraine this week have revived anxiety among Ukrainian officials and civilians over one of the most oppressive hardships of the war: a winter assault on their nation’s energy grid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Kids of Rutherford County, Episode 2: ‘What the Hell Are You People Doing?’
description: A young lawyer can’t get a juvenile court to let his clients out of detention — even when the law says they shouldn’t have been held in the first place.
content: A young lawyer named Wes Clark begins defending children at the Rutherford County juvenile court. He quickly sees a troubling pattern: Kids are jailed for minor offenses, even when the law says they shouldn’t be. But he can’t always persuade the juvenile judge to let them out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush
title: Federal Prosecutors Push to Reinstate Gag Order on Trump
description: In court filings, the special counsel’s office said the gag order was needed to keep the former president from making “harmful and prejudicial attacks” on people in the federal election case.
content: For much of this week, after a federal judge temporarily froze the gag order she imposed on him, former President Donald J. Trump has acted like a mischievous latchkey kid, making the most of his unsupervised stint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘After Death’ Review: Visions at the Brink From Those Who Returned
description: A documentary about near-death experiences crescendos with redemptions and literal come-to-Jesus moments.
content: The faith film “After Death” enters a crowded field of testimonials about near-death experiences, a staple of YouTube videos and bookstores. This documentary convenes a supergroup of writers and survivors: from early expounders like the author Raymond Moody (widely credited with coining the term “near-death experience”) and the cardiologist Michael Sabom, to such recent best-selling names as the pastor Don Piper (“90 Minutes in Heaven”) and a surgeon, Mary Neal (“To Heaven and Back”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: ‘Lyonesse’ Is a Starry Mess
description: In London, Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas do their best in a new play that careers between near-slapstick one minute and speechifying the next.
content: “We dream big,” says a no-nonsense film executive early in “Lyonesse,” the starry, if overstuffed, new play that opened Wednesday night at the Harold Pinter Theater, in London. And so, too, does this West End debut from Penelope Skinner, a British playwright whose works have long enlivened small theaters on both sides of the Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Slovakia Says It’s Halting Arms Deliveries to Ukraine
description: The newly appointed prime minister, Robert Fico, whose party aligned with pro-Russian forces during the recent election campaign, had promised “not to send a single cartridge” of ammunition to Kyiv.
content: Slovakia, a small Eastern European nation that has been in the vanguard of sending arms to Ukraine, says it is halting all military aid to its embattled neighbor, a policy shift that is unlikely to change the balance of forces on the battlefield but that delivers a symbolic blow to Kyiv at a time of growing fatigue in parts of Europe after 20 months of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Are ‘Secret Room’ Drawings by Michelangelo? Now, Visitors Can Judge for Themselves.
description: Since its discovery nearly 50 years ago, a room beneath the Medici Chapels in Florence covered in sketches has been closed to the public. Next month, that will change.
content: The narrow, arched room below the Medici Chapels Museum in Florence has some suspiciously virtuosic doodles on the walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, David Yaffe-Bellany and J. Edward Moreno
title: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Testimony Is Delayed at Fraud Trial
description: The founder of the collapsed FTX crypto exchange will testify on Friday, after the judge decided to hold an evidentiary hearing on Thursday.
content: The wait for Sam Bankman-Fried’s testimony before a jury will be a little longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: In a Democratic District, Can a Party Defector Get Elected?
description: A contest between two New York City councilmen, Justin Brannan and Ari Kagan, will measure how strong the rightward shift is in southern Brooklyn.
content: At a public housing complex in Coney Island, Brooklyn, a powerful Democratic councilman sought to quickly make the case for why voters should reject his opponent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Four Daughters’ Review: The Role Family Plays
description: This documentary from Kaouther Ben Hania restages pivotal moments from a family’s life.
content: Re-enactment is not an unusual or particularly novel tool in documentary filmmaking yet recently it seems to have made a pointed resurgence — perhaps because the method has a distinct relationship to trauma and offers a compelling means of picking open old wounds for cathartic and/or healing purposes. Think “Framing Agnes,” “Procession,” and Nathan Fielder’s HBO series “The Rehearsal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon Revenue Jumps as Consumer and Business Spending Improves
description: Investors were closely watching business spending with the company’s cloud computing division, which grew 12 percent in the most recent quarter.
content: Amazon reported solid quarterly sales on Thursday, showing that corporations and consumers are spending as inflation has eased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: New House Speaker Champions Fossil Fuels and Dismisses Climate Concerns
description: Representative Mike Johnson comes from Louisiana oil country and has said he does not believe burning fossil fuels is changing the climate.
content: Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana, the newly elected House speaker, has questioned climate science, opposed clean energy and received more campaign contributions from oil and gas companies than from any other industry last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Maria Cramer
title: Israel-Hamas War Protest Leads to Tense Scene at Cooper Union Library
description: A video shared on social media showed pro-Palestinian protesters pounding on one side of locked library doors and Jewish students on the other.
content: The tensions inflamed by the Israel-Hamas war that have roiled university campuses in the United States spilled into the Cooper Union in New York on Wednesday, with pro-Palestinian protesters pounding on one side of locked library doors and Jewish students on the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittani Samuel
title: ‘The Great Gatsby’ Review: A Musical Take on Tragic Desire
description: This new version of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic remains largely faithful to the novel, but it trades subtle prose for a straightforward production.
content: F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The Great Gatsby” requires no critical endorsement. His slim 1925 novel still takes up permanent residence in the book bags of students across the nation. Often it is crushed under tomes of greater size, but what “Gatsby,” lacks in length it makes up for in heart, opulence and tragedy. A new musical adaptation trades Fitzgerald’s subtle blend for a blunter approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Trumpism Is Running the House
description: Mike Johnson’s election as speaker shows that Trumpism now lies at the core of Republican politics.
content: The three-week battle to choose a House speaker may be over, yet the fallout for the United States and its reputation as a sound government and a beacon of democracy will be long-lasting and profound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: ‘Is He Going to Make It?’: A Mother Waits for News
description: Jessica Karcher’s son, Justin, was shot four times and is in critical condition at Central Maine Medical Center in Lewiston.
content: For hours and hours on Wednesday night, Jessica Karcher waited at the Central Maine Medical Center in Lewiston for news of her son Justin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The G.O.P. Goes Full-on Extremist
description: When intolerance meets reactionary economics.
content: There are no moderate Republicans in the House of Representatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Schools and Public Buildings in Southern Maine Close as Manhunt Continues
description: Dozens of government buildings, school districts and universities in the state are closed, following advice from the authorities for residents to shelter in place.
content: As the police in Maine continue their search early Thursday for the suspect, dozens of government buildings, local school districts and universities in the southern portion of the state are closed, following advice from the authorities for residents of the area to stay home or shelter in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: Israel’s Army Is Ready to Invade Gaza. Its Divided Government May Not Be.
description: In the 20 days since Hamas attacked, Israel’s Air Force has pounded Gaza and its troops have gotten into position. But its leaders disagree about what to do next.
content: Its troops are massed on the Gaza border and described as ready to move, but Israel’s political and military leaders are divided about how, when and even whether to invade, according to seven senior military officers and three Israeli officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: What’s Happening in the Bond Market?
description: The rapid rise in interest rates in recent months has shaken investors and cast a cloud over the economy.
content: The interest rates on mortgages, credit cards and business loans have shot up in recent months, even as the Federal Reserve has left its key rate unchanged since July. The rapid rise has startled investors and put policymakers in a tough spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Virginia Republicans Look to Neutralize Abortion as an Election Issue
description: The state’s governor, Glenn Youngkin, has a strategy to win the state. If it halts Democrats’ momentum on the issue, it could be a model for the party in 2024.
content: Abortion has been a losing issue at the polls for Republicans across the country since the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. But now in Virginia, which holds elections in early November, the party thinks it has hit upon a formula to stop the electoral drubbings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: View From the West Bank
description: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro and Times journalists on the ground.
content: There are fears that the Israel-Hamas war could expand into the West Bank, an already combustible and tense region, where the Israeli military has just carried out another round of arrests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron
title: After ‘Shaft,’ 8 Movies to Watch Featuring Black Action Heroes
description: “Shaft,” starring Richard Roundtree, created a template for Black action protagonists onscreen.
content: As unthinkable as it now seems, the role of John Shaft, paragon of movie star Black masculinity, was very nearly cast as a white character. Executives at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer wanted to flip the source material — a 1970 novel about a Black private detective — for white audiences. But the director Gordon Parks’s vision for the treatment convinced the studio to cast in the role the model and actor Richard Roundtree, who died Tuesday at 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Dave Chappelle Laments ‘Nightmare’ Facing Israelis and Palestinians
description: The comedian, whose remarks about the Israel-Hamas war last week made headlines, returned to the subject at a show in North Carolina.
content: Dave Chappelle was about 24 minutes into his set on Wednesday night in Raleigh, N.C., when he briefly touched on remarks he had made about the Israel-Hamas conflict at a show in Boston last week that had led to cheers, some walkouts and headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno and Matthew Goldstein
title: Close Confidants of Sam Bankman-Fried Have Testified at His Trial
description: From his former girlfriend and colleague to high-ranking FTX executives, Sam Bankman-Fried’s trial has featured many people close to him.
content: Over the past three weeks, former employees and friends of Sam Bankman-Fried have testified that he orchestrated a scheme to misappropriate billions of dollars in customer money from his FTX cryptocurrency exchange, which collapsed last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Desperate to Make Her Mother Smile, Nina Simon Wrote a Book
description: The author of “Mother-Daughter Murder Night” started working on her debut novel during a time of tremendous stress.
content: “I had never expected to write a novel,” Nina Simon said in a phone interview. “But then in August of 2020, I got a phone call that changed my life.” The call was from her mother, Sarina Simon, announcing that her recent cognitive decline had been caused by brain tumors that would require surgery. Later, the Simons learned that Sarina had lung cancer. “I proceeded to very rapidly switch from this life of running nonprofit organizations to caregiving for my mom,” Nina Simon said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Jarnot
title: Poem: Suddenly, Last Summer
description: Developing, through ecstatic repetition, a theology of lostness.
content: Lisa Jarnot’s “Suddenly, Last Summer” develops, through ecstatic repetition, a theology of lostness. The sea-turtle hatchlings, with their instinctual desire to move toward light, risk this desire’s fatal consequence when knowing no better, they mistake the neon lights of the beach for the guiding light of the moon and stars over the water. So, too, the human voice of the poem begins lost — ready to worship but bereft of a God. In the “blue blue night” of despair, human and animal alike retain a creaturely innocence. Even the title — a pop-culture hand-me-down — underlines the innocence and ordinariness of a shared and painful predicament, the guiltless way any of us might find ourselves heading in the wrong direction. The small and unsatisfying light of the library and the deceptive brightness of the neon instigate the poem’s revelation: By these small lights, and with our fellow creatures, we learn there is a greater light to which we may return. Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Israel: From the Six-Day War to the Six-Front War
description: Threats to Israel are multipronged, including Iran and its proxies but also narratives from Western progressives and social media, Palestinians in the occupied territories and internal divisions.
content: If you care about Israel, you should be more worried than any other time since 1967. Back then, Israel defeated the armies of three Arab states — Egypt, Syria and Jordan — in what became known as the Six-Day War. Today, if you look closely, you’ll see that Israel is now fighting the Six-Front War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: The Flatiron Building Will Be Converted Into Condos
description: The storied office building will receive a second life as home to roughly 40 residents, according to the owners.
content: The Flatiron, the storied office building in the heart of Manhattan that has recently fallen on hard times, will be converted into luxury housing, its owners announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Gaya Gupta
title: Several Family Members of Al Jazeera’s Gaza Bureau Chief Are Killed
description: Wael al-Dahdouh, described by his colleagues as “the voice of Palestinians in Gaza,” lost his wife, son, daughter and infant grandson, Al Jazeera said.
content: The following video includes graphic images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: What Is Going On in Britain’s Economy? The Picture Is Foggy.
description: The country’s statistics agency published new “experimental” labor market data, the latest in a series of economic re-evaluations.
content: It might never be possible to know precisely how an economy is performing in any given moment. But recently it has gotten harder to get a clear picture of Britain’s economy, particularly the labor market.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Our recommended books this week have a decidedly British cast, with a new history of the marriage between Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn, an analysis of Shakespeare and race, a Welsh memoir and a group biography of the eccentric logophiles who contributed to the Oxford English Dictionary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Biden calls for more aid into Gaza.
content: President Biden called for more aid into Gaza and assurances that the help was reaching those who needed it most amid a growing humanitarian crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: The ‘Total Stranger’ Who Wants You to Relive Your Dating Disasters on Camera
description: J.C. Carter was luckless in love. So, tiny microphone in hand, he started “Hopeless Romantic Society” to find others like him.
content: “What’s the craziest thing you ever did for love?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: For Many in Wyoming, a Biden Plan to Protect Land Is Beyond Unpopular
description: Explosive reactions to the proposal, which would limit drilling, show how the president’s climate policies are crashing into walls in some oil and gas states.
content: Of all of the efforts by the Biden administration to protect environmentally fragile lands, few have generated as much vitriol as a proposal that would block oil and gas drilling on 1.6 million acres of high desert sagebrush steppe in Wyoming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Teenagers on What They Have Learned From Failure
description: “Failure only has the power that you give it.”
content: Failure is a part of life. But most of us try to avoid it and are embarrassed when things go wrong. Instead, experts say, we should try to embrace our mistakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: PinkPantheress’s Music Broke the Internet. Up Next? Everything Else.
description: The 22-year-old British singer and producer learned to do things for herself early on. With “Heaven Knows,” a new album out in November, she’s preparing for bigger stages.
content: On a recent September evening at Nickelodeon Universe, the cavernous indoor theme park tucked into an East Rutherford, N.J. mall, the 22-year-old British pop musician PinkPantheress was perched 10 stories above the ground, gleefully waiting to ride Shredder, billed as the world’s tallest free-spinning roller coaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A New Generation of Artists in Roy Lichtenstein’s Studio
description: The Whitney Museum has acquired the artist’s former space, once a metalworking studio, in the West Village.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out what has happened to the studio in the West Village where the artist Roy Lichtenstein worked from the late 1980s until his death in 1997. We’ll also find out about how parking tickets figured in a court ruling on owning guns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart and Lanna Apisukh
title: The Clothes Are Old. New Yorkers’ Love for Them Is Ageless.
description: The Manhattan Vintage Show featured Victorian-era diamonds, flapper dresses from the 1920s, motorcycle jackets from the 1990s and so much more.
content: Sofia Wallis held up a delicate lace garment, in awe of its history. “This is an original 1930s puff-sleeve wedding gown, and I have a photo of the original bride on her wedding day,” she said. “It’s from Texas. And I have the original box and where it was bought and everything.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Hamas leaders arrive in Moscow as the Kremlin attempts to showcase clout.
description: The meetings with high-ranking members of the group that attacked Israel underscored how Russia is trying to present itself as an alternative platform for possible mediation.
content: A group of high-ranking members of Hamas arrived in Moscow on Thursday, meeting with a senior Russian official in what looked like an affront to the West aimed at demonstrating how the Kremlin still holds sway over key players in the bloody conflict in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Denmark Aims a Wrecking Ball at ‘Non-Western’ Neighborhoods
description: A government program is using demolition and relocation to remake neighborhoods with immigrants, poverty or crime.
content: After they fled Iran decades ago, Nasrin Bahrampour and her husband settled in a bright public housing apartment overlooking the university city of Aarhus, Denmark. They filled it with potted plants, family photographs and Persian carpets, and raised two children there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jake Sullivan’s ‘Quieter’ Middle East Comments Did Not Age Well
description: The national security adviser has drawn criticism for recent public remarks. Biden officials pushed back on the idea that Mr. Sullivan was offering a lasting view on Middle East conflicts.
content: In a 7,000-word essay for Foreign Affairs magazine published this week, Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, tried to sum up the state of the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Inspector Sun’ Review: A Web of Cinema Classics
description: The newly released English version of this Spanish children’s film about an arachnid gumshoe is a comic mystery indebted to Agatha Christie and swashbuckling epics.
content: “Inspector Sun,” a computer-animated family film released in Spain last year and now arriving in an English-language dubbed version, is very clearly a product of the director Julio Soto Gurpide and the screenwriter Rocco Pucillo’s deep affection for motion picture history. The movie draws on a range of classics, from silent adventure serials to screwball mysteries like “The Thin Man” to the swashbuckling epics of Douglas Fairbanks and Errol Flynn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Must Return Buddhist Statue to Japan, Supreme Court Says
description: The artifact, which was taken to Tsushima centuries ago, was stolen and smuggled back to South Korea by thieves in 2012.
content: The Supreme Court of South Korea ruled on Thursday that a Buddhist statue currently in government custody must be returned to a Japanese temple, ending a decade-old dispute between temples ​in both countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Search Boss Says Company Invests to Avoid Becoming ‘Roadkill’
description: At the start of its antitrust defense, Google attributed its success to relentless investment, countering government claims that it broke the law to stay ahead.
content: The Justice Department has spent weeks arguing in a federal antitrust trial that Google has built an impenetrable barrier around its search business with strong-arm tactics and multibillion-dollar deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Inside Google’s Plan to Stop Apple From Getting Serious About Search
description: Google has worried for years that Apple would one day expand its internet search technology, and has been working on ways to prevent that from happening.
content: For years, Google watched with increasing concern as Apple improved its search technology, not knowing whether its longtime partner and sometimes competitor would eventually build its own search engine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Henry Winkler’s Dream Dinner Guests Wrote for Stage, Page and TV
description: “I know my limitations, but I would still invite William Shakespeare,” says the actor, whose new memoir is “Being Henry: The Fonz … and Beyond.” “I would also invite Daniel Silva and definitely Larry David!”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘Yellow Door: ’90s Lo-Fi Film Club’ Review: Cinema Education
description: This documentary is both a look at a small, obsessive film club that formed in the early ’90s in South Korea and an origin story of the director Bong Joon Ho, who was in the group.
content: Every filmmaker, including the great ones, starts somewhere — even if that means making a low-rent stop-motion short called “Looking for Paradise” that’s about a stuffed gorilla searching for freedom while fighting a caterpillar that emerged from its fecal matter. That was how a young, student Bong Joon Ho made his debut, a saga detailed in “Yellow Door: ’90s Lo-Fi Film Club,” a charming documentary about a cohort of South Korean cinephiles formed in 1992.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: This Kids’ Show Is ‘Indiana Jones in Reverse’
description: In “Curses!,” a spooky animated series debuting Friday on Apple TV+, an archaeologist’s family deals with the consequences of looted artifacts.
content: Jeff Dixon wants to frighten your children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Searching for Humanity in the Middle East
description: The Israel-Gaza conflict has destroyed certain assumptions about the world order and pushed us closer to nihilism.
content: We’re living through an era of collapsing paradigms. The conceptual frames that many people use to organize their understanding of the world are crashing and burning upon contact with Middle Eastern reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn and Thea Traff
title: The Scientists Watching Their Life’s Work Disappear
description: Some are stubborn optimists. Others struggle with despair. Their faces show the weight they carry as they witness the impact of climate change.
content: Amid the chaos of climate change, humans tend to focus on humans. But Earth is home to countless other species, including animals, plants and fungi. For centuries, we have been making it harder for them to exist by cutting down forests, plowing grasslands, building roads, damming rivers, draining wetlands and polluting. Now that wildlife is depleted and hemmed in, climate change has come crashing down. In 2016, scientists in Australia announced the loss of a rodent called the Bramble Cay melomys, one of the first known species driven to global extinction by climate change. Others are all but certain to follow. How many depends on how much we let the planet heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing: Israel Says Tanks Briefly Entered Gaza
description: Plus inspiration in the Rugby World Cup final.
content: The Israeli military said yesterday that it had briefly sent tanks into the northern Gaza Strip overnight as part of preparations for the next stage of fighting, after the prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, indicated that the country was likely to carry out a ground invasion of the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Monster Cookies, Chocolate Peanut Butter Cups and Popcorn Balls
description: Lots of Halloween treats, none of them tricky.
content: We’re firm believers that when it comes to Halloween, there’s no reason the kids should have all the fun. (They’re likely to take all the chocolate for themselves and stick you with stale Smarties and rock-hard Tootsie Rolls.) In our collection of Halloween cookie and candy recipes, you’ll find dangerously simple chocolate peanut butter cups, delightfully retro popcorn balls and, of course, Nigella Lawson’s monster cookies (above). Those cookies, by the way, as well as these kitchen sink cookies and these Rice Krispies treats with chocolate and pretzels, are a great way to use up fun-size Snickers and Milky Ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: U.S. Economic Growth Accelerated in the Third Quarter
description: Gross domestic product expanded at a 4.9 percent annual rate over the summer, powered by prodigious consumer spending. But the pace is not expected to be sustained.
content: The United States economy surged in the third quarter as a strong job market and falling inflation gave consumers the confidence to spend freely on goods and services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli and Julia Jacobs
title: A Britney Spears Book Tour: No TV, No Podcasts, Lots of Instagram
description: The singer, who has not given a face-to-face interview since 2018, has avoided traditional public appearances for “The Woman in Me,” which is still finding audiences.
content: In the run-up to the release of his blockbuster autobiography earlier this year, Prince Harry sat down with “60 Minutes” — and “CBS Mornings,” “ABC News Live,” “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” and others. Paris Hilton did “The View” and spoke with the BBC. Kerry Washington appeared on NPR’s “Fresh Air” and “Good Morning America.” Arnold Schwarzenegger opted for Kelly Clarkson and Howard Stern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Mom’s Favorite Chicken Dinner Gets a Makeover
description: Melissa Clark takes mustardy, bread crumb-laden thighs to new heights.

author: By Maggie Astor
title: North Carolina Republicans Approve House Map That Flips at Least Three Seats
description: The gerrymandered congressional map, made possible by a new G.O.P. majority on the state Supreme Court, ensures Republican dominance in a closely divided state.

source.name: The New York Times

title: Suspect in Killing of Maryland Judge Is Found Dead

title: Judge John Hodgman on the Tangled Yarn

content: Erin writes: I started crocheting during lockdown. Recently, I made the mistake of washing seven skeins of yarn at once, turning them into a giant wad. It took two days to untangle one skein. My husband says I should throw the wad away because the time spent untangling could be better spent crocheting. Who’s right?
source.name: The New York Times

title: At the Australian State Dinner, Jill Biden Stays Neutral
description: The first lady wore a dress by designer Reem Acra.
content: It was a night of comfort food and canny comfort dressing — strange adjectives for a state dinner, an event normally known for pomp, circumstance and grand gowns. But everything is relative, and these are complicated times, demanding a careful balance between displays of power and humility in the face of other people’s pain.
source.name: The New York Times

title: European Central Bank Keeps Rates on Hold for First Time in Over a Year

title: Billions of Years Ago, Venus May Have Had a Key Earthlike Feature

content: Venus today is not like Earth. Temperatures hover around 860 degrees Fahrenheit day and night, and clouds of sulfuric acid float in its atmosphere.

title: Maine Mass Shooting Is America’s 8th, and Deadliest, This Year

content: Before a gunman in Maine, who has yet to be captured, killed 18 people and wounded 13 more in Lewiston on Wednesday night, there had been seven mass shootings in the United States this year, with the most recent one occurring in mid-July. But the shooting in Maine is the country’s deadliest of the year.

title: What ‘Oddball Rituals’ Do You Have?

title: What We Know About the Maine Shooting Suspect
description: Robert R. Card, who is being sought by the authorities,is an Army reservist, according to Pentagon records. A neighbor said several generations of his family had lived on farmland in southern Maine.
content: The authorities in Maine said an arrest warrant citing eight counts of murder had been issued for Robert R. Card, the 40-year-old man they were seeking in connection with the shootings Wednesday night at a bowling alley and bar in Lewiston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Rick Rojas
title: Georgia’s Voting Maps Are Struck Down
description: Republicans in the state violated a landmark civil rights law in drawing maps that diluted the power of Black voters, a federal judge in Atlanta ruled.
content: Republicans in Georgia violated a landmark civil rights law in drawing voting maps that diluted the power of Black voters, a federal judge in Atlanta ruled on Thursday, ordering that new maps must be drawn in time for the 2024 elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: With War Raging, Colleges Confront a Crisis of Their Own Making
description: Education and validation aren’t the same.
content: For the past two and a half weeks, college leaders have canceled or anxiously discussed canceling campus speeches and events that touch on Israel and Palestine. They’ve agonized over the wording of official school statements about the Oct. 7 massacre in Israel and, in some cases, issued second statements to amend, augment or atone for the first ones.
source.name: The New York Times

title: These Boxers Plan to Show They Can Fight by Men’s Rules
description: When Amanda Serrano and Danila Ramos meet in the ring Friday night, they will spar for 12 three-minute rounds, following the format used for men’s fights.
content: When Amanda Serrano trains for a championship fight, she often spars with men for at least a dozen three-minute rounds, using the standard male regulation format to push her athleticism to the edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Chimpanzees Go Through Menopause, Too
description: A new study challenges a prominent evolutionary theory about why women live long after their childbearing years.
content: For biologists, menopause is baffling. If natural selection favors genes that produce more descendants, why don’t women remain fertile their entire lives? What’s the evolutionary benefit of living for so many years without having more babies?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: 3 Ways to Unlock Your ‘Hidden Potential’
description: In his new book, the organizational psychologist Adam Grant shares counterintuitive strategies for higher achievement.
content: In a culture that focuses so intensely on success, it’s easy to feel like a failure. But according to the organizational psychologist Adam Grant, that might be because we’re thinking about achievement all wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Khaite Clothes, Made Miniature
description: Plus: a ’70s-inspired hotel in London, jewelry made with river pebbles — and more.
content: The Khaite designer Catherine Holstein was newly pregnant in the fall of 2022 when the French children’s wear brand Bonpoint reached out to her about collaborating on a capsule collection. Now, the 11 new designs, intended to fit babies and children up to 10 years old and made with materials that are gentle against sensitive skin, are launching on Oct. 25 with a campaign featuring Holstein’s now-seven-month-old son, Calder. Standout pieces include a billowy white cotton top with a ruffled collar, a whimsical red-and-white botanical print skirt and miniature versions of two Khaite mainstays: a double-breasted Tanner blazer and a wool version of the brand’s flare-sleeved Scarlet cardigan. “I’m just amazed at the conversations you can have with kids after the age of three, and what their perspective is,” says Holstein. “I wanted the collection to give them the option to really home in on their individuality.” The pieces most dear to the designer are those inspired by her 1980s childhood. “I had black corduroy overalls that I would wear with suspenders with cars on them and a Fair Isle cardigan. … I really wanted to capture that nostalgia.” From $110, khaite.com and bonpoint.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Siemens Energy in Talks With German Government for Financial Help
description: Financial problems at the company, a major supplier of wind turbines and power plants, could hamper the energy transition.
content: Siemens Energy, a major European manufacturer of wind farms, power grids and natural gas turbines, said Thursday that it was in talks with the German government about securing financial guarantees to help it continue to build future large projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Dave Chappelle and the Perils of Button-Pushing Comedy
description: His comments on the Mideast conflict have been the subject of news reports, but the polarizing coverage has ignored how comics have treated the situation.
content: Halfway through a sold-out show at the PNC Arena in Raleigh, N.C., on Wednesday, Dave Chappelle stopped to ask the audience about screaming coming from the balcony. “I’m scared it might be the Jews coming for me,” he said, a mischievous tone in his gravelly voice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: It’s the Great Pumpkin Veggie
description: Save the big field pumpkins for carving (and roasted pumpkin seeds) and reach for a can to make coconut curry chickpeas, creamy pumpkin soup and a sheet-pan pancake.
content: With Halloween looming ominously in the distance, allow me to regale you with a spooky tale. You’re in the canned goods aisle at your grocery store, on the hunt for the season’s hottest commodity: pumpkin. You grab a couple of cans of purée, visions of cheeky jack-o’-lanterns dancing in your mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Remy Tumin
title: Driver of N.Y.P.D. Tow Truck Hits and Kills 7-Year-Old Boy
description: The child, who was on his way to school, was riding a scooter next to his mother in the Fort Greene neighborhood of Brooklyn when he was hit in a crosswalk.
content: A 7-year-old boy was killed in Brooklyn on Thursday morning when the driver of a Police Department tow truck hit him while he was crossing the street, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why the U.A.W.’s President Has Taken a Hard Line
description: Shawn Fain owes his rise within the United Automobile Workers to a group determined to make the union far more confrontational toward automakers.
content: When Shawn Fain sought the presidency of the United Automobile Workers union last year, he ran on a platform that promised: “No corruption. No concessions. No tiers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: As ‘Billions’ Ends, Its Creators Discuss the Changing Face of the Ultrarich
description: In an interview, the showrunners discussed its imminent conclusion and the rise of billionaires who believe they are “making the world a better place.”
content: As the Showtime financial thriller “Billions” prepares to air its final episode this weekend, it’s worth considering how far we’ve come. The show started as the story of the crusading U.S. Attorney Chuck Rhoades (Paul Giamatti) and the hard-charging hedge funder Bobby Axelrod (Damian Lewis). Exclusive restaurants, elaborate schemes and a host of cameos by real-world power players provided the backdrop for their battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Trying for a Mortgage? Here’s How Much Money You Need to Make.
description: Qualifying incomes for standard mortgages on typical homes have gone through the roof. Especially in California.
content: The minimum income needed to qualify for a typical mortgage on a median-price home is higher than ever. The culprits: rising interest rates, high home prices and low inventory.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Prosecutors Withdraw Second Subpoena in Trump Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: The decision suggests that the special counsel is winding down an investigation into whether the former president’s political operation defrauded investors by promoting election lies.
content: Federal prosecutors have quietly withdrawn a subpoena seeking records from former President Donald J. Trump’s 2020 campaign as part of their investigation into whether Mr. Trump’s political and fund-raising operations committed any crimes as he sought to stay in power after he lost the election, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Ohio Woman Fatally Drugged 4 ‘Johns’ She Met for Sex, Officials Say
description: Rebecca Auborn, 33, indicted on four counts of murder and other felonies, drugged a series of men before stealing their possessions, according to prosecutors. There may be more victims, they say.
content: She met the “johns” for sex in northeast Columbus, Ohio, then drugged them with fentanyl, stole their possessions, and left them for dead, state prosecutors said. All told, they said, the woman killed four men from January to June.

description: Matthieu Rytz’s documentary about the bounty at the bottom of the sea examines the fight over whether to reap these riches or preserve them.
content: Documentaries on ecological crises often begin by scaring the bejesus out of viewers before adding a note of tempered optimism. For “Deep Rising,” a film about the race to mine the deep seabed (in particular, the floor beneath the Pacific’s vast Clarion-Clipperton Zone), the director Matthieu Rytz eschews shock for awe, and inflammatory rhetoric for measured persuasion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anita A. Summers, Economist, Dies at 98; Brought Rigor to Public Policy
description: As a professor at the Wharton School and a pioneering woman in a male-dominated field, she developed new ways of thinking about tough issues.
content: Anita A. Summers, an economist at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania who injected quantitative rigor into a wide variety of public policy topics, including zoning, education and tax incentives, died on Sunday at her home in Gladwyne, Pa. She was 98.

title: ‘No Gas, No Water, No Food’: Otis Devastates Pacific Coast of Mexico
description: The storm was one of the strongest ever to hit the southwest coast, and the Mexican government dispatched thousands of troops to the region.
content: Sitting in his empty cab on Thursday as another taxi driver pushed it from behind, Miguel Ángel Dorantes surveyed the scene of devastation left by the most powerful hurricane to hit the Pacific coast of Mexico, wondering if he would be able to reach home. Mudslides blocked off his hillside house in Acapulco. Basic goods were scarce because of aggressive looting following the storm.

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli

content: The first of the two shootings in Lewiston, Maine, took place at a bowling alley, interrupting an American pastime on an ordinary Wednesday evening.

description: “Now and Then,” an unfinished composition from the late 1970s, was completed using technology that separated John Lennon’s vocal from a piano track.
content: “Now and Then,” a recently finished recording from the late 1970s that is being billed as the “last song” by the Beatles, will be released on Nov. 2, more than half a century after the group broke up, thanks to advancements in audio technology, the band’s remaining members announced Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Morgan Stanley Names Ted Pick, a Bank Veteran, Its Next C.E.O.
description: Mr. Pick’s ascension caps an unusually public three-way race to replace James Gorman, who presided over steady growth after taking over in 2010.
content: Morgan Stanley, one of Wall Street’s most prestigious banks, said on Wednesday that it had chosen Ted Pick, a three-decade veteran of the firm, to be its next chief executive, ending an unusually public three-way race that James Gorman, the chief executive since 2010, once jokingly compared to the television series “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosa Lyster
title: Looking Past the Gadgets, and Into Spies’ Minds
description: There are plenty of crowd-pleasing tools and weapons in a London exhibition about espionage. But spying is about more than cool stuff.
content: A tube of lipstick hiding a miniature camera, issued to female K.G.B. spies during the 1970s. A box of matches containing message-writing tools, used by British double agents in World War II. A Russian-designed cassette player with secret compartments for surveillance equipment. A hollow battery in which an MI6 operative could store reels of miniature film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: ‘Make Noise Enough’: Excavating Shakespeare’s Songs
description: In Shakespeare, music is an integral part of the action. But the First Folio, which turns 400 this year, failed to transmit how it should sound.
content: Musicians from the early-music ensemble Collectio Musicorum were practicing a 17th-century round on a recent afternoon in Manhattan. The tune was jaunty, full of the cantering rhythms and mimetic horn calls that fit a song about hunting. But sung in canon, some of the notes bumped roughly against one another in daring dissonance. The singers broke off, looking at their conductor for guidance.
source.name: The New York Times

content: The tropical storm off the coast of southern Mexico looked as if it might bring some heavy rain to the tourist haven of Acapulco.

author: By Hanna Notte
title: Putin Is Getting What He Wants
description: Russia is emerging as a major beneficiary of the war in Gaza.
content: As Israel and Hamas descend into all-out war, Russia has been more of a bit player than a lead actor. There is no evidence that Moscow directly aided or abetted Hamas’s vicious attack against Israel on Oct. 7, despite some early suggestions. Diplomatically, too, the Kremlin has been of negligible significance, unable to defuse the metastasizing tensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Gazans Release Names of 6,747 People They Say Were Killed in Israeli Strikes
description: The detailed list from the Hamas-controlled health ministry — including ages, genders and ID numbers — followed President Biden’s comment that he had “no confidence” in its figures.
content: The Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza has released a list of 6,747 people it said had been killed in Israel’s relentless bombardment of the Palestinian territory in retaliation for the Hamas-led raid on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people in Israel.

content: Donald J. Trump could not hide his anger. Sitting at the front of a crowded New York courtroom this week, he folded his arms tightly across his chest. He tossed his head and scowled. He stared into the middle distance and scrolled through his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Five Nights at Freddy’s’ Review: Creepypizza
description: This adaptation of a video game franchise is more interested in unpacking childhood trauma than packing in jump scares.
content: A workweek’s worth of graveyard shifts should offer ample time to convert an overwrought trauma plot into a congenial camp scare-fest. But although “Five Nights at Freddy’s,” based on a popular video game franchise, reaches for horror-comedy flair, this dreary, mild adaptation never achieves the hybrid pleasures of a movie like “M3gan.” You may chuckle, but it’s hard to tell if the movie is laughing with you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘The Holdovers’ Review: Three Sad Souls Stranded for Christmas
description: Alexander Payne’s jaunt to the past, with Paul Giamatti playing a curmudgeonly instructor at a 1970s boarding school, is crackling with pungent life.
content: “The Holdovers” takes place in New England somewhere, in 1970, at a tony, all-boys boarding school called Barton, where the students who can’t go home for Christmas wind up spending their breaks in the care of Paul Hunham (Paul Giamatti), the sourest, most pompous instructor the movie can find. He teaches ancient civilizations and prides himself on being the sort of principled educator who flunks senators’ kids and says stuff like, “Such are the vicissitudes of life” and “Listen, you hormonal vulgarian!” He smells bad, and breaks into Greek and Latin as much out of spite as bonhomie. The man can read everything but the room.

title: Artists of Color Ask: When Is Visibility a Trap?
description: In “Going Dark” at the Guggenheim, 28 artists explore urgent questions around what it means to be seen, and to see each other.
content: Your first encounter in the Guggenheim Museum’s ambitious new show, “Going Dark: The Contemporary Figure at the Edge of Visibility,” is likely to be with four looming figures draped in voluminous garments. It’s hard to see if anyone (or anything) is underneath the slightly futuristic hoodies. Acid-green projected light — known as chroma green, used by film studios for “green screen” effects — bathes the big gallery off the rotunda. The result is paradoxical — the figures are so huge they should be unmissable, but with this intense illumination you may have trouble making them out.
